The former title of this section was Estate Tax Installments. The title is being changed to reflect that this section has been expanded to address all special election accounts, in addition to installment cases under IRC section 6166.

on Accounts with Special Estate Tax Elections 5.5.6 page 1

) This section contains background information and procedures for Collection employees who must perform actions on accounts that were granted special elections under the Internal Revenue Code (IRC). Collection field are responsible for collection of terminated special election accounts that assigned to them. (

) Responsibilities for determining qualification, processing and billing of elections are coordinated between Exam Estate & Gift Speciality Tax and Estate & Gift Tax unit in the Cincinnati Campus. These responsibilities are outlined in IRM
, Estate and Gift Tax Examinations and IRM
, Campus Procedures For Estate Tax. (

) The Advisory Estate Tax Lien group is responsible for making concerning securing special election liens or bonds to protect the interest during the extended deferral period. These responsibilities are in IRM
, Estate Tax Liens. (
) Knowledge of the responsibilities of these functions will enable Revenue Officers to secure the information needed to assist with investigation and lution of collection cases. (
) IRC section
provides an extension of time to pay Form
estate tax annual installments. Generally the maximum amount of time for payment of
deferred tax is

years. The executor may select a shorter period, in which case the deferment will be the period selected. It allows executors a year period to pay estate tax attributable to an estate’s interest in a closely held business. It grants the estate a deferral period to make “interest only” payments for the first four years. The first tax payment along with interest payment is due on the
th anniversary of the due date of the return. See

IRC section
provides an extension of time to pay Form
estate tax in annual installments. Generally the maximum amount of time for payment of deferred tax is

years. The executor may select a shorter period, in which case the deferment will be the period selected. It allows executors a fourteen year period to pay estate tax attributable to an estate’s interest in a closely held business. It grants the estate a deferral period to make “interest only” payments for the first four years. The first tax payment along with interest payment is due on the

If the deferred tax due is the result of an examination deficiency, the estate must make the election within 60 days after issuance of notice and demand.

) An interest in closely held business is defined as: (cid:
) A proprietorship that carries on a trade or business. (cid:

percent more of the total capital interest in the partnership or the partnership has

percent or of the value of voting stock of the corporation is included in the gross estate, or the corporation has

) IRC section
(h) provides for the election to defer the deficiency tax resulting from an examination, if the estate is not already making payments under IRC section
The IRC section
) election must be made within
days of the issuance of the notice and demand. The deficiency is prorated per the formula in IRC section

(a). The estate cannot defer than the deficiency. The estate may not elect to defer any portion of a defi- ciency that was due to negligence, intentional disregard of rules and regulations, or fraud with intent to evade tax. (
) IRC section
(e) provides for the proration of deficiency installments if estate is paying in installments under IRC section

when the is made. The part of the deficiency attributable to the closely-held business shall be prorated and added to the installments. The deficiency portion of an installment that is due and payable when the deficiency assessment is shall be paid upon notice and demand. (

IRC section 6166(g)(1) provides for acceleration of installments. The of installments are accelerated upon notice and demand if:
(cid:

) The election may be terminated because the estate fails to provide (lien or bond) to the Service for tax due, if the Service has determined that security is necessary. The Service may make this determination at the of the estate’s IRC section
election or it may make the determination at some point during the IRC section

installment agreement. Most likely this will happen when the estate has failed to pay after requesting an extension of an annual installment payment or when the Service deter- mines that the underlying business may be in financial difficulty. (

) When accelerated, the estate will be sent a series of letters from the Advisory Estate Tax Lien group and the Campus concerning termination and demand the tax due. Advisory procedures are explained in IRM
, Special Lien Under IRC §
A for Estate Tax Deferred under IRC Section
, and Campus procedures in IRM
, Miscellaneous IRC Section
Campus Termination Issues. (

) Copies of termination letters provide a payoff of the full amount of tax due to specified date. This payoff can be used for collection purposes until the estate provides a date it will pay the account in full. Since the account was in Status

, the campus will need to provide a payoff when necessary. Advisory should also have copies of termination letters in their case files and copies of liens, bonds or financial information secured from the estate. (
) Once an account has been accelerated, it cannot be reinstated for reasonable cause. An account can be reinstated only if a valid extension of time to pay (under IRC section

) has been filed for the amount in question prior to due date or the account was erroneously accelerated due to a processing error. A processing error is one in which a timely payment was treated as late or posted to the wrong account or type of tax. These errors should be rare an account should be reinstated only if it meets these guidelines. Neither Ex- amination nor Collection has the authority to request reinstatement of an account other than in the above circumstances. (
) A balance due account may be assigned to the field while the estate is appealing allowance of the IRC section
election. IRC section
does not prevent collection of the tax while the taxpayer is appealing the determination regarding the estate’s section
election to the Tax Court. (
) Section
(a) generally prevents any court from stopping collection unless one of the exceptions applies. An exception applies if the taxpayer has not yet been given an opportunity for hearing under section

, or if the taxpayer has timely requested a hearing. Except in cases of jeopardy, levy is prohibited until the taxpayer is issued a notice giving the taxpayer a right to a hearing to contest levy and the taxpayer fails to make a timely hearing request. Levy is also prohibited during a timely requested hearing and judicial review of the termination resulting from that hearing. During the administrative hearing or court proceeding, the Tax Court may permit levy under section

) if liability is not at issue and the Service shows good cause. Good cause exists when the Service shows that the taxpayer is maintaining the hearing or pro- ceeding for purposes of delay, the taxpayer is raising frivolous arguments, or the government will be harmed by the suspension. In this regard, special attention should be given to whether the levy suspension will harm the ment’s ability to enforce its Section
lien rights before they expire.

the estate fails to make all of an annual installment payment within

months of the due date. The election may be terminated because the estate fails to provide security (lien or bond) to the Service for tax due, if the Service has determined that security is necessary. The Service may make this determination at the time of the estate’s IRC section
election or it may make the determination at some point during the IRC section

installment agreement. Most likely this will happen when the estate has failed to pay after requesting an extension of an annual installment payment or when the Service deter- mines that the underlying business may be in financial difficulty.
A balance due account may be assigned to the field while the estate is appealing allowance of the IRC section
election. IRC section
does not prevent collection of the tax while the taxpayer is appealing the Secretary’s determination regarding the estate’s section
election to the Tax Court. Section
(a) generally prevents any court from stopping collection unless one of the exceptions applies. An exception applies if the taxpayer has not yet been given an opportunity for hearing under section

, or if the taxpayer has timely requested a hearing. Except in cases of jeopardy, levy is prohibited until the taxpayer is issued a notice giving the taxpayer a right to a hearing to contest levy and the taxpayer fails to make a timely hearing request. Levy is also prohibited during a timely requested hearing and judicial review of the de- termination resulting from that hearing. During the administrative hearing or court proceeding, the Tax Court may permit levy under section

) if liability is not at issue and the Service shows good cause. Good cause exists when the Service shows that the taxpayer is maintaining the hearing or pro- ceeding for purposes of delay, the taxpayer is raising frivolous arguments, or the government will be harmed by the suspension. In this regard, special attention should be given to whether the levy suspension will harm the govern- ment’s ability to enforce its Section
lien rights before they expire.
Decedent Estates and Estate (
) Section
allows for collection of an amount determined as a deficiency while a Tax Court decision is being appealed to the Circuit Court unless the taxpayer posts a bond. (
) Should you receive an account to collect estate taxes and the IRC
election is either in Appeals or Tax Court for reconsideration, consult with the Counsel attorney assigned the case to determine if collection can proceed should be withheld. (
) Counsel should consider whether the underlying tax amount is in dispute, much time remains on the IRC section
(a) lien and collection potential remaining estate assets when providing guidance concerning continuation of collection . (

) The laws granting the estate tax installment election provide the Service certain options to secure eventual payment. These options include: Liens and Bonds a. Requiring the estate to furnish a performance bond in an amount equal IRC

the estate tax and interest being deferred. Bonds must be renewed annually and documentation provided to the Service verifying renewal. b. Allowing the estate to substitute the bond with the filing of a special lien under IRC section
A (Form
-J) pledging their right, title, and interest to specific property to the government. (
) The Advisory Estate Tax Lien group is responsible for making determinations concerning securing special election liens or bonds to protect the interest during the extended deferral period. See IRM
, Advisory Lien Determinations for Estate Tax Deferred under IRC Section

5.5 Decedent Estates and Estate
The laws granting the estate tax installment election provide the Service certain options to secure eventual payment. These options include:

Requiring the estate to furnish a performance bond in an amount equal to the estate tax and interest being deferred. Bonds must be renewed annually and documentation provided to the Service verifying renewal. Allowing the estate to substitute the bond with the filing of a special lien under IRC section
A (Form
-J) pledging their right, title, and interest to specific property to the government.

The Advisory Estate Tax Lien group is responsible for making determinations concerning securing special election liens or bonds to protect the Governments interest during the extended deferral period. See IRM 5.5.8.5.1, Advisory Bond/ Lien Determinations for Estate Tax Deferred under IRC Section 6166.
There will not be a IRC section
A lien in every case where the Service has agreed to a IRC section

installment election. The Service will make a determination after the election whether it will need security based on the facts and circumstances of each case. The Service may require the estate to secure a bond. The estate may elect the IRC section
A lien in lieu of securing a bond.

-J is insufficient to pay the estate full, then any other property that remains attached by the IRC section lien (including the like lien) and/ or the IRC section
liens are subject enforcement action. Distributees of the estate property also may he held as transferees. (
) Always check the Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED) when estate tax accounts. IDRS does not accurately reflect the CSED when assessments are involved or when an IRC section
election has been granted. (
) For accounts with an approved IRC section
election, the CSED is suspended for the period during which payment of the tax is deferred, see section
(d). However, running of the IRC section
(a) estate lien is not suspended. (

) Once you determine the correct CSED, document your ICS history with the new CSED and how you arrived at the date. Be sure that the module is also updated on ICS. (
) Payoffs for IRC section
accounts will need to be secured from the Campus E&G unit. Once an account goes into status

you can no longer a payoff through IDRS. If IDRS reflects manual assessments of penalty and interest, accrued penalties and interest need to be computed. For campus contacts see:http://mysbse.web.irs.gov/Collection/toolsprocesses/Estat
ax/ Estat
ax/default.aspx (
) After an IRC section

account is accelerated the Campus closes their case file. Partial information regarding these accounts are maintained on database. The Campus may need to secure additional information from the collection case file or order their closed file in order to provide a payoff. (

) Copies of termination letters issued by the Campus provide a payoff of the amount of tax due to a specified date. This payoff can be used for collection purposes until the estate provides a date it will pay the account in full. should also have copies of termination letters in their case files and copies liens, bonds or financial information secured from the estate. (
) Once the status
is input, FTP and interest need to be calculated and manually input. The last TC

on the account will reflect to what date the interest has been updated. When a collection account assigned to the field is paid in full the revenue officer is required to request input of the penalties interest to the date of payment to prevent refunds. (
) The manual assessment can be requested on Form
when posting received or if the funds have posted request the assessment on Form
) Submit a Form
, Request for Terminal Action, to the CCP Fort to assessment of accruals once the balance due is paid. If there is a TC
beginning with a DLN
on the account, send your request to the Cincinnati CCP Unit at *SBSE CCP Exam Cincinnati. If the return has not been examined, send your request to CCP Fort in Philadelphia. (
) Do not abate penalties or interest assessments made by the Campus in dance with their IRM provisions - unless you verify there was a Service error. (
) When computing payoffs on estate tax accounts, be aware that the estate may qualify for an interrelated payoff computation. (
) When Form

is filed, deductions against the gross estate have been claimed for the expenses incurred in administering the estate. After the has been filed, additional expenses may be incurred for which the estate can claim a deduction by filing an amended return. Such expenses include fees, accounting fees, interest due on state estate tax liabilities unpaid at the time returns are filed, and state death tax credits that have been paid in ments. Allowable expenses are explained in IRC section
Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
Y
The manual assessment can be requested on Form 3244 when posting funds received or if the funds have posted request the assessment on Form 4844.
Do not abate penalties or interest assessments made by the Campus in accor- dance with their IRM provisions - unless you verify there was a Service error.

) Any additional deductions, including interest as a debt, must be requested writing by the estate or by submitting a supplemental return. On a balance account, interest as a debt may be limited to only the interest that has been paid, instead of all interest that is due. (

) If all or a portion of the estate tax has been deferred under IRC section the estate may request a recomputation of the tax due based on allowed tional expenses. The supplemental return with documented expenses must provided to the E&G
unit at the Campus in order to do the interrelated computation with special software and provide a payoff. (
) Tax decreases on amended and/or interrelated computations, will not be without the taxpayer’s agreement and/or payment in full per the new tion. (

The property covered by the lien for the IRC section 2032A election is the interest in the qualified real property. The property covered by the lien for the IRC section 2057 election can be either real or personal property.
